maintenanceevent.eventdescription: Finding aid encoded by Glenn R. Gardner

did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Lawyer, state legislator, and United States representative from Alabama. Correspondence, letter books, legal record books, journals, dockets, notebooks, and an unpublished autobiography of P. Phillips, relating chiefly to the law practice of P. Phillips and his son, W. Hallet Phillips, both of whom practiced before the Supreme Court. Contains the writings of P. Phillips's wife, Eugenia, including her journal written while interned during the Civil War, and of her parents, Jacob Clavius Levy and Fanny Yates Levy.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Lamar, L. Q. C. (Lucius Quintus Cincinnatus), 1825-1893--Correspondence.
Levy, Fanny Yates, 1787-1891 or 1892. Fanny Yates Levy papers.
Levy, Jacob Clavius, 1788-1875. Jacob Clavius Levy papers.
Phillips, Eugenia Levy. Eugenia Levy Phillips journal. 1861-1862.
Phillips, W. Hallett (William Hallet), 1853-1897. W. Hallett Phillips papers.

corpname.part: United States and Mexican Claims Commission.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of P. Phillips, lawyer, state legislator, and United States representative from Alabama; his son, W. Hallett Phillips, lawyer; and other members of the Levy and Phillips families were obtained by gift, deposit, and purchase between 1900 and 1917 from P. Lee Phillips of Washington, D.C. In 1945 the remaining deposits were converted to a gift.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The papers of the P. Phillips family were described and arranged in 1962. The finding aid was revised in 2011.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright in the unpublished writings of the P. Phillips family is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The papers of the P. Phillips family are open to research. Researchers are advised to contact the Manuscript Reading Room prior to visiting. Many collections are stored off-site and advance notice is needed to retrieve these items for research use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Container number, P. Phillips Family Papers, Manuscript Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Delegate to South Carolina State Constitutional Convention (nullification)
Member, South Carolina house of representatives
Admitted to United States Supreme Court
Member, United States House of Representatives, 33rd Congress
Began law practice in Washington, D. C.

chronitemset.event: Wife, Eugenia Levy Phillips, interned for Confederate sympathies
Family sent south to Crany Island via Fort Monroe as suspected spies for Confederate States of America.
Began New Orleans, La., bar practice

chronitem.event: Wife, Eugenia Levy Phillips, confined to Ship Island as rebel spy and finally released by Benjamin Butler as prisoner of war after three months
Began law practice in La Grange, Ga., and New Orleans, La.
Removed to Washington, D. C., and resumed United States Supreme Court practice
Graduated, Columbia College, Washington, D. C.
Special agent to investigate conditions in Yellowstone National Park

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Although Eugenia Levy Phillips was an ardent Southerner, as shown in her journal written during her internment, P. Phillips apparently played an inactive role in the Civil War. There is a gap in the otherwise inclusive series of letterbooks for the period 1862 to 1867, but the period is scanned in his autobiography. Both P. Phillips and his son were champions of the disadvantaged. The elder Phillips was interested in California and the United States and Mexican Claims Commission, Key West and the slave trade, judicial reform, and in securing the repeal of the Missouri Compromise with the passage of the Kansas-Nebraska Act.

There is little biographical material on W. Hallett Phillips, but something of his character can be gleaned from his notebooks, translations and miscellaneous writings. His idealism is shown in material on the preservation of Yellowstone National Park, support of the Cuban revolution, investigation of a lynching at Hahnville, Louisiana, and the defense of the rights of the Moki (Hopi) Indians of Arizona.

Correspondence is generally on legal matters and includes James B. Campbell, Edmund Strother Dargan, John Forsyth, George Wilkins Guthrie, John Marshall Harlan, William R. King, William A. Maury, Medill McCormick, Moses Cohen Mordecai, Richard Olney, Hoke Smith, Edwin McMasters Stanton, A. B. Stickney, and William Yerger.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Papers
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in eight series:

scopecontent.p: Holograph transcript and typed transcript of the journal of Eugenia Levy Phillips.

Washington, D. C. law office letterbooks of Philip Phillips; Phillips, Maury, & Phillips; W. Hallett Phillips; and Phillips & Phillips. There is some overlapping between volumes and a gap in the records of Philip Phillips for the period 1862-1867.

arrangement.p: Arranged by name of firm and chronologically thereunder.

did.unittitle: W. Hallett Phillips, 1875, Aug.-1885, June; Phillips & Phillips, 1883-1884

arrangement.p: Arranged by subject or type of material.

scopecontent.p: Autobiography, printed speeches and statements, and "In Memoriam," of P. Phillips, and miscellaneous writings and translations of W. Hallett Phillips.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous writings, notes, and translations of W. Hallett Phillips

scopecontent.p: Deeds, will, Supreme Court brief, dockets, legal notebooks, and record books of Philip Phillips; Phillips, Maury, & Phillips; and W. Hallett Phillips.

did.unittitle: Supreme Court brief, Key v. Frelinghuysen, undated
Docket book of W. Hallett Phillips, 1867-1878

Index and digest of
Wallace's Reports , United States Supreme Court, 1877
Docket of United States Supreme Court
Legal notebook of W. Hallett Phillips

scopecontent.p: Ledger, account books, receipt books, cancelled checks, and fee memorandum.
Commonplace books, receipt books, scrapbooks and notebooks, a copy of "Vindiciae Judaeorum," a book of quotations, notes and invitations, memorabilia, photographs, and printed matter.

did.unittitle: Memoirs of an Hungarian Lady , by Theresa Pulszky (Philadelphia, 1850)
Receipt book, poetry, and related material, Samuel Yates Levy, 1857-1871
Legal notebook, W. Hallett Phillips, 1871, undated
Book of quotations, W. Hallett Phillips, 1875
